meanings.sent1: His constant teasing would enrage his little sister.
meanings.sent2: The loud noise from the construction site would enrage the neighbors.
meanings.sent3: The mischievous puppy managed to enrage the grumpy old cat.
meanings.sent4: The unfair decision by the referee seemed to enrage the entire crowd.
meanings.sent5: The careless driver's actions could enrage even the most patient person.

meanings.definition: To cause someone to become enraged.
meanings.sent1: The unexpected news would enrage her father.
meanings.sent2: The rude behavior of the customer would enrage the store manager.
meanings.sent3: The silly prank managed to enrage the usually calm teacher.
meanings.sent4: The betrayal by a close friend can enrage even the most forgiving person.
meanings.sent5: The sight of litter on the beach can enrage environmental activists.
